patterns.title: Complete Map of Time
patterns.subtitle: Past, Present, Future, Eternal
patterns.description: The four quadrants touch every dimension of time—past, present, future, and the eternal now.
patterns.whyItMatters: When we only focus on the urgent present, we lose context and vision. This framework ensures you're connected to all of time—rooted in the past, present in this moment, asking eternal questions, and envisioning the future.
patterns.reflection: Which dimension of time do you naturally gravitate toward? Which do you avoid?
patterns.ldsExample: Mission work (present), temple worship (eternal), family history (past), gathering Israel (future)

patterns.title: The Cross/Axis Structure
patterns.subtitle: Transcendent & Grounded, Past & Future
patterns.description: The framework forms a cross when mapped as coordinates—horizontal (time) and vertical (dimension).
patterns.whyItMatters: Integration requires bridging apparent opposites—transcendent and grounded, past and future. This framework literally enacts that integration through its structure.
patterns.reflection: Do you tend to live more on the horizontal axis (time-focused) or vertical axis (dimension-focused)? What would balance look like?
patterns.ldsExample: Heaven and earth, past and future—the cross pattern appears in temple architecture and covenant theology

patterns.title: Every Relationship You'll Ever Have
patterns.subtitle: Self, Other, Source, Lineage, Community
patterns.description: Each quadrant engages a different primary relationship.
patterns.whyItMatters: Human wholeness requires all four relationships. When any one is neglected, we become unbalanced. This framework ensures no relationship is forgotten.
patterns.reflection: Which relationship feels most alive for you right now? Which needs attention?
patterns.ldsExample: Living neighbors, God through covenant, ancestors, gathering Israel into community

patterns.title: Four Ways of Knowing
patterns.subtitle: Empirical, Inspired, Historical, Intuitive
patterns.description: Each quadrant represents a different epistemology—a different way humans discover truth.

mapping.observe: Empirical knowing (through direct experience and senses)
mapping.ask: Inspired knowing (through opening to guidance beyond yourself)
mapping.remember: Historical knowing (through story, record, and lineage)

patterns.whyItMatters: We're often taught to privilege one way of knowing, but truth comes through all four channels. This framework honors every way humans can discover what's real.
patterns.reflection: Which way of knowing feels most natural to you? Which have you been taught to distrust?
patterns.ldsExample: Personal experience, revelation in the temple, family history records, prophetic vision

operationMapping.OBSERVE: Empirical knowing (through direct experience and senses)
operationMapping.ASK: Inspired knowing (through opening to guidance beyond yourself)
operationMapping.REMEMBER: Historical knowing (through story, record, and lineage)

patterns.title: Four Positions at the Threshold
patterns.subtitle: Here, At, Beyond, Unified
patterns.description: The framework engages boundaries from every angle—working on this side, standing at the edge, reaching to the other side, and envisioning wholeness.

mapping.observe: This side of the boundary (the present, known, visible)
mapping.ask: At the threshold (liminal space between states)
mapping.remember: The other side (what's distant, past, or beyond awareness)

patterns.whyItMatters: Every meaningful framework must bridge different states of being—present and absent, known and unknown, visible and invisible. This pattern ensures you're not stuck on just one side.
patterns.reflection: What boundary are you working with right now? Which of the four positions feels most needed?
patterns.ldsExample: Working with the living, temple as threshold, reaching to ancestors across the veil, gathering toward unity

operationMapping.OBSERVE: This side of the boundary (the present, known, visible)
operationMapping.ASK: At the threshold (liminal space between states)
operationMapping.REMEMBER: The other side (what's distant, past, or beyond awareness)

patterns.title: Four-Phase Oscillation
patterns.subtitle: The Rhythm of Expansion and Contraction
patterns.description: The framework pulses through four distinct phases—intake, pause, release, rest—creating a natural rhythm found in breath, action-contemplation cycles, and all living systems.

breath.ask: Hold at the top (pause, fullness, contemplation)
breath.imagine: Hold at the bottom (emptiness, potential, before new creation)

actionContemplation.remember: Active research (doing the work, building connections)

patterns.whyItMatters: The framework literally breathes. It's rhythmic, cyclical, life-giving. You can't rush it. You can't skip steps. It moves at the pace of life itself. All action with no contemplation leads to exhaustion. All contemplation with no action leads to stagnation. This pattern builds sustainable rhythm into the cycle.
patterns.reflection: Can you feel the oscillation rhythm in your practice? What phase are you in right now? Are you more naturally oriented to intake/release or to the pause states?
patterns.ldsExample: Receive from missionary work, pause in temple worship, release through family history service, rest before beginning again

derivation.manualOverride: Consolidated from Action-Contemplation Rhythm + Breath Cycle into unified RHYTHM pattern

patterns.title: Four Functions of Consciousness
patterns.subtitle: Sensation, Thinking, Feeling, Intuition
patterns.description: Carl Jung identified four fundamental ways the psyche processes reality. This framework maps perfectly to them.
patterns.whyItMatters: Jung argued that psychological wholeness requires developing all four functions. Most people have one or two that dominate. This framework ensures you're touching all four, even if some feel uncomfortable.
patterns.reflection: Which function is your 'home base'? Which one challenges you most?
patterns.ldsExample: Serving others (sensation), seeking answers in temple (thinking), connecting with ancestors (feeling), envisioning gathering (intuition)

patterns.title: The Cycle of Transformation
patterns.subtitle: How All Growth Happens
patterns.description: This is literally how all growth, healing, and learning happen—in any domain.

mapping.step3: REMEMBER — You integrate it with your story (context provides meaning)
mapping.step4: IMAGINE — You envision how to move forward (possibility emerges)
mapping.step5: Back to OBSERVE — You notice what changed

patterns.whyItMatters: This is how therapy works. How education works. How scientific discovery works. How spiritual awakening works. The framework isn't prescribing anything artificial—it's describing the natural cycle of human development.
patterns.reflection: Where are you in this cycle right now with your biggest current challenge?
patterns.ldsExample: Notice a neighbor's need → ask in prayer → remember similar situations → imagine how to help → observe the outcome

patterns.title: Fractal (Scale-Free) Structure
patterns.subtitle: The Same Pattern at Every Scale
patterns.description: The same 4-part cycle repeats at every scale, from micro to cosmic.

mapping.micro: One conversation: notice what they need → ask how to help → recall similar situations → envision what's possible
mapping.daily: One day: morning awareness → midday pause for reflection → afternoon integration → evening planning
mapping.lifetime: One lifetime: present awareness → seeking understanding → integrating your story → envisioning legacy
mapping.cosmic: All time: current moment → eternal questions → honoring what came before → vision of ultimate wholeness

patterns.whyItMatters: Because it's fractal, you can practice this at any scale. You don't need to 'do big things.' The pattern works in a 5-minute interaction just as well as in a 40-year life arc.
patterns.reflection: What's the smallest scale where you could practice this today?
patterns.ldsExample: From a single conversation to an entire dispensation—the pattern of observe, ask, remember, imagine repeats at every level

derivation.manualOverride: Category manually set to STRUCTURAL - scale invariance is a geometric property of the matrix

patterns.title: Diagonal Integrity
patterns.subtitle: Self-Reference vs. Cross-Pollination
patterns.description: The matrix diagonal distinguishes pure self-operations (OBSERVE-OBSERVE, ASK-ASK, etc.) from hybrid cross-operations that integrate different verbs.

mapping.offDiagonal: Cross-pollination operations (verb applied to different verb)

offDiagonal.description: 12 hybrid operations where one verb acts upon another

patterns.whyItMatters: The diagonal reveals the symmetry spine of the matrix: self-referential operations create reflexive awareness and integration, while off-diagonal operations create new synthesis. Without the diagonal, you miss the difference between deepening a single mode and bridging between modes.
patterns.reflection: Do you tend to stay on the diagonal (deepening single modes) or move off-diagonal (bridging between modes)? What does your pattern reveal about how you process experience?
patterns.ldsExample: ASK-ASK: questioning your questions in personal worship vs. REMEMBER-ASK: carrying earlier questions back into the present

patterns.title: The Pattern of Discovery
patterns.subtitle: How Humans Learn Truth
patterns.description: This is how humans discover truth in any domain—secular or sacred.

mapping.imagine: Theory (propose what could be, test predictions)

patterns.whyItMatters: The framework isn't 'religious vs. scientific.' It's how consciousness itself works. Science and spirituality use the same underlying pattern because it's the pattern of discovery itself.
patterns.reflection: Have you been taught that faith and inquiry oppose each other? What if they're the same motion?
patterns.ldsExample: Notice a need, pray for guidance, study the scriptures and family records, envision how to move forward

operationMapping.IMAGINE: Theory (propose what could be, test predictions)

patterns.title: Receptive and Active Energy
patterns.subtitle: The Dance of Receiving and Initiating
patterns.description: The quadrants alternate between receptive and active energy, creating dynamic balance.

mapping.remember: Receptive (receiving from the past, being taught)

patterns.whyItMatters: Neither receptive nor active energy is privileged. Both are essential. The framework won't work if you only do half. You need to receive AND initiate, rest AND act.
patterns.reflection: Which energy feels more natural to you? What would it mean to honor both?
patterns.ldsExample: Receive in missionary work, initiate in temple worship, receive from ancestors, initiate in gathering

derivation.manualOverride: Type changed to RHYTHM - represents alternating oscillation pattern along axis

operationMapping.REMEMBER: Receptive (receiving from the past, being taught)

_metadata.note: Type classifications and categories are computationally derived from structural signals

categories.STRUCTURAL: Geometric properties inherent to the 4×4 matrix
categories.COMPLETENESS: Proofs that the 4×4 maps exhaustive category systems
